39303484.review:
(Note: This review was written after chapter 4's release. If the final fifth chapter impacts this review, I will update it accordingly. I am also a man.)

Female-driven visual novels have become increasingly common among western audiences. Unfortunately, these games are also peppered with groan-inducing young boys seeking to win the hearts of adolescent girls through affection. Where are the games with dark storytelling and evil men, and why is it taboo for women to fantasize about them? Demonheart wisely accommodates this void with a cast of evil love interests and a thought-provoking dark narrative.

To understand the nuances of Demonheart, we must trace its origins back to the PC game, Neverwinter Nights. Demonheart originated as a mod, given life as this visual novel. This visual novel is mostly a rehashed story from the mod; however, there are enough new surprises to satisfy returning players, especially since the original mod was never finished.

The major flaw in transitioning Demonheart from an action role-playing game to a visual novel is the difference in scope. When we subtract the combat and exploration, what's left is a condensed story barely enough to qualify as a short visual novel, clocking in at about ten hours. Regardless, the story expertly weaves a powerful narrative into these limited hours, and the universe the story provides leaves open the possibility for future sequels.

The protagonist is a beautiful young woman named Bright. She can be anything the player wants, from honest and affectionate to deceitful and cruel. One feature that faithfully makes its transition from Neverwinter Nights is that everything Bright says is produced through the player selecting decision prompts. Typical visual novels only provide these opportunities a few times a game; Demonheart provides hundreds. Admittedly, most of these decisions are an illusion of choice, but because the player won't always know what decisions impact the story, it's suspenseful nonetheless. Bright will be presented a number of evil (or good) opportunities to provide an outlet for a player's dark fantasies while the game monitors her progress with a built-in alignment system.

The alignment system, unfortunately, feels a bit superficial. In just 20 minutes, the player can max out their choice of alignment. Most games use alignment as a progression system to track the player over an entire narrative, but in Demonheart it feels tacked on to accommodate returning Neverwinter Nights players. Nonetheless, its inclusion is a feel-good ego boost for players to have the peace of mind knowing their good or evil decisions are having an impact.

Demonheart is a dark story, and the weight is carried by its antiheroes, Brash and Raze. Both are potential love interests, imposing their sexual emotions upon Bright. Brash is a powerful and irritable knight, openly disdaining anyone he remotely disagrees with. He's also incredibly sexist and brutally honest about it. Meanwhile, Raze is a demon working from the shadows, whispering dark suggestions into Bright's head and isn't shy about conquering her. Most games driven by female protagonists exhibit bad-boys as basic delinquents; in Demonheart, these bad-boys are genuinely evil men, exhibiting  ruthlessness and sexual perversions uncharacteristic of most female protagonist games.

These perversions are given further clarity with voice acting. For a small-scale visual novel, I was nervous at its inclusion; voice acting when done poorly can ruin an otherwise great game. The developer wisely invested time into patiently selecting a commendable cast of performers. The voice acting ranges from below average to impressive. The worst is from Bright's mother, who lacks enthusiasm. The best performances, thankfully, are from the main supporting actors, Brash and Raze who perfectly capture their personalities. The two have a unique accent as Brash possesses a rough demanding voice while Raze presents himself as a suave sophisticated playboy. Sometimes, they can deliver a line that falls flat, or perhaps their microphone is too close or far from their face, but it's rare enough to ignore.

The artwork for the characters and the fictional world they inhabit is both distinct and beautiful. The characters possess a combination of striking eyes with normal human features, possibly inspired from Neverwinter Night's fantasy portrait art. The backgrounds share details from old oil paintings, which is a pleasant comparison to the story's dark fantasy setting. Some early critics shared animosity at early impressions of the game's artwork, but after seeing the totality of the artistic marriage, I am convinced the art is successful.

One major omission from the art in contrast to its Neverwinter Night's mod is the sex. The mod was not under sexual scrutiny from Steam, allowing for a different depiction of the characters, especially Brash. That version of Brash was a sex-craved addict who practiced what he preached, consequently making him more unpredictable and dangerous. By comparison, Brash in the visual novel is still violent, but stops short at having sex, as if he knows he's being monitored by the ratings board. Not even the protagonist calling him "queer" impacts Brash, for under the watchful eye of parents, Brash knows his hands are tied as he's met his match. Oh, but don't worry, it's totally fine if he kills people, right?

Demonheart may lack in explicit sex, but it still provides an unforgettable unique story showcased by its powerful and sexually suggestive cast of antiheroes. It explores a dark female-driven narrative appealing to both male and female audiences, and succeeds better than some had originally thought at the transition from a Neverwinter Nights mod to full-fledged visual novel. Oh, and Lamb, if you're reading this, write a sex scene into the chapter 5 ending. Cut to black if you have to. 

[b]Final Score: 9/10.[/b]

This game was a hidden gem for me! It didn't think it would be that good as there's quite a lot of these on steam but after I started playing I really got sucked into the story!

As there's only three chapters out so far I'd give it like an 7/10 recommend.

The story is interesting and keeps you entertained. The artwork is nice and the characters are too. There are plenty of options when responding to events in the game and it actually feels like most of your choices matter. A lot of these games make it so obvious that you need to select specific answers in order to get very specific outcomes, but with this one I was able to play how I wanted to and have the story end up the way I wanted without having to follow any kind of guide and on my first play through; Maybe I was just lucky though. I like that not all answers affect your character's personality which adds a bit more depth to the story while giving more flexibility in how you choose your answers.

A few wishes for the game though, would be:

*A longer story. 
This isn't to say I'm not happy with the length of the chapters because they are quite long and fleshed out but I don't think that five chapters is enough for what you pay compared to other games of this kind, I know some of those games are dirt cheap and the good ones can charge a LOT but they are pretty good quality and I see that kind of potential here. I bought the game with 20% off and feel like it was quite worth it at that price ($15). In saying that I would be happy to pay around $30 for ten chapters each with the same chapter length that is already there, realistically. But that's just my own opinion.

*More characters that impact the story would definitely be a plus.
Having only two characters that it seems like you can romance doesn't seem like quite enough. Maybe another two would make it more interesting but you'd need to be careful not to let this take away from each character's story/personality.

*More CG's in the story.
You really only get one or two good CG's in the three chapters that you can play. I'm not expecting to get much more because there is only supposed to be five chapters coming out and this is really disappointing. The artwork in this game is good and the creators would definatley benefit from putting more CG's into the game.

So far I recommend buying this only with the sale until all the chapters come out at least (:

34050169.review:
[h1]An episodic dark fantasy VN where your character is shaped entirely by your choices be they good or bad.[/h1]

[i]Note: Episodes 3-5 will be released as free updates if you already have the game[/i]

You are Bright, a young woman living in the slums with her parents in a peaceful little town. Everything changed, however, when the Fire Nati--wait, I mean until a witch named Orchid requests your presence. What could this possibly mean? Dark times of course.

[h1]Gameplay/Controls[/h1]
The game’s choices are entirely up to you. The story is an interesting one full of betrayal, death, resurrection, and a whole lot of debauchery. The voice acting is pretty good too. There aren’t spoken lines all the time, but when there is, it accentuates the story’s plot points, giving depth and personality to the characters. The voice work is quite nice and aren’t grating or out of place. The Demon in your head is especially witty.

So, you arrive to talk to Orchid after the summons, but soon find there are others who are meeting with her as well; a boy, a mean wench, and a rather suspicious looking hooded girl by the name of Ari. Orchid holds a contest to see who will work for her. You can select whichever choices you want when the moment comes, but if you’re curious about how the responses will be, you can always save in the pause menu and reload.

You can also see how your responses are shaping your character overall. The character alignment shows various personalities Bright will take on depending on which answer you choose. There is Good/Evil and Tactful/Defiant. I’m on the Tactful/Defiant alignment because I found myself immediately disliking Mark, Bright’s betrothed. So I never responded nicely to him. You get the option later to [spoiler]kill Mark using a potion you can choose to keep when you’re released from the dungeon[/spoiler]. And I so did it, no remorse. :) 

You’ll have instances where you decipher Demon Speak which is sort of like Scrabble, unscrambling words. You will also be identifying key objects of interest with your mouse in some scenes that will reveal more about the location you’re in or more about the plot.

The one thing that often pulled me out of the story were the expletives. Some of them were alright and fit with the story and lore. Other times, they felt a little out of place with certain situations and dialogues because it caught me off guard or came out of nowhere. 

Controls use a mouse to either click or select things on screen, so there’s not much to it.

[h1]Graphics/Music[/h1]
The art is gorgeous. The attention to each character and detail brings out their personality. Even more so when you hear their voices. The one thing that also stood out to me was that the world feels alive. The characters breathe and blink, smirk or squint. They feel more 3-dimensional for a VN where most of the time, the characters are images that don’t move at all. Very nice touch.

The music is also fitting for the story and works well to build suspense and add to the drama overall. 

[h1]Overall[/h1]
I highly recommend Demonheart. It’s a very different VN that does some things others have, but better. I enjoyed the voice work, the depth of the different characters, and the strange and mysterious story unfolding.

Episode 3 is slated to release August 21st, 2017 and I will definitely be all over that. So, if you enjoy VNs with some dark humor, gorgeous artwork, interesting cast of characters, and the ability to fully flesh out your protagonist and align them how you want, Demonheart is definitely one to pick up.

A full choice story game with romance and violence that doesn't control your every move? You better believe it. 

For the first time, I was actually shocked and delighted such a well designed visual novel existed. I really wish I could draw more attention to this game.

With their ambiently animated cast, it really added that tiny bit of realism into them so you didn't feel like you were just talking to a portrait like a low budget otome. You can feel as if you have more to look at than just words.

The characters were all fleshed out and ANY questions that arose were excellent for story progression and (HIDDEN) answers. 

Really well thought out in the fact that normally, whatever you feel as your own personal reaction to a situation will be a choice you can make. These heavy choices may be taken lightly, but they can alter your 'alignment' throughout your story; which actually DOES affect how characters react to you, or how things happen to you in the story; especially with your 'Infernal Patron'.

The story holds strong and may seem a bit fast paced if you're really rushing through to devour the story, or if you're a fast reader. Sometimes even I felt that it moved a bit fast, even for no reason. Honestly, I don't suggest blazing through this like some cheaply made Visual Novel or Otome. There is a lot of underlying story you need to pay attention to.

However, it holds a very "colorful"(dangerous) world and somewhat predictable backgrounds. Sometimes, it feels like your choices don't really matter- and there are no threats to speaking your mind (Or simply opting to be a bitch) other than a character becoming annoyed with you for 2 seconds. There are times when a character may say or do something that won't make any sense, either- especially if you didn't gather everything storywise along the way. There was one time in which even that wasn't an excuse, and a character may become very... odd.

The backstory for each character (pointing fingers to the patron) gives you the insight to the bigger picture, which is very important to not be blindsided later on; and is in general, worth replaying to test all the choices to find them. It took me personally 3 playthroughs to realize my 'patron' didn't know what a goat was, and he seemed to have a great distaste for things the player could know or have read during the game. Either way, he might not take kindly to every choice you make. This 2nd main character is made up of your choices (Somewhat?? but is mostly an infernal ball of sass). All in all- he's very worth the play to 'meet' in the new chapter.

Voice acting was the only SLIGHT negative as it was picked only for some lines. While sometimes you might expect something important spoken, it likely won't be, even if the comedic effect would worked better that way. 

I personally really loved what was available for this game, and truly and honestly recommend it for people who want to really feel inclusive in a story or play as a woman capable of being a badass 'don't need no man' type. 

I'll also say to buy it BEFORE it is complete, as the creators might raise the price.

It is a bit short ( 77 min. for first playthrough ), but when all the chapters are out it will be a very complete game very much worth the price. Sincere thanks to the team who made this game possible, and I am eagerly waiting for more.
